name: Multiplication and division with standard form 2

skills.name: Perform division calculations using standard form

explanations.A: This is 0.004, think about the place value of the numbers to see if we would get such a small answer
explanations.B: This is 4000. Think about the place value of the 2 in 2 x 10^5, and what would happen to this if it was divided by 500
explanations.C: You're almost there. Think about rewriting 2x10^5 as an ordinary number, and then dividing by 500.
explanations.D: 2 x 10^5 is 20 000. When divided by 500 the answer is 400. In standard form 400 is 4 x 10².

explanations.A: Almost. Start off by changing 3x10^4 into an ordinary number first and then divide by 60
explanations.B: Almost. Think about rewriting 3x10^4 as an ordinary number, and then divide by 60.
explanations.C: 3 ×10^4 = 30000. Dividing this by 60 = 500. Changing 500 into standard form = 5×10².
explanations.D: This is 0.05, think about the place value of the numbers to see if we would get such a small answer

explanations.A: It looks like you have divided the indices. Think about the law of indices needed when the same base number is divided.
explanations.B: We have (5 × 10^12)/(2 × 10^4). We can then work out 5/2 and (10^12)/(10^4) separately. When dividing indices with the same base number, the powers are subtracted. 5/2 is 2.5, so (5 × 10^12)/(2 × 10^4) becomes 2.5 × 10^(12 – 4), which is 2.5 × 10^8
explanations.C: It looks like you have subtracted the numbers and powers. With standard form, the laws of indices are only applied to the indices. You will need to divide the number
explanations.D: You seem to have mixed up the rules for when indices are subtracted or divided. When dividing base numbers that are the same, indices are subtracted. You will need to divide the numbers

explanations.A: It looks like you have subtracted the numbers and powers. With standard form, the laws of indices are only applied to the indices, you divide the numbers
explanations.B: You seem to have mixed up the rules for when indices are subtracted or divided. When dividing base numbers that are the same, indices are subtracted. The numbers are divided
explanations.C: It looks like you have divided the indices. Think about the law of indices needed when the same base number is divided.
explanations.D: We have (5 × 10^16)/(4 × 10^2). We can then work out 5/4 and (10^16)/(10^2) separately. When dividing indices with the same base number, the powers are subtracted. 5/4 equals 1.25, so (5 × 10^16)/(4 × 10^2) becomes 1.25 × 10^(16 – 2), and equals 1.25 × 10^14.

explanations.A: It looks like you have divided the indices. Think about the law of indices needed when the same base number is divided.
explanations.B: To write an answer in standard from: a x 10^b, a must be between 1 and 10
explanations.C: It looks like you have divided the indices. Think about the law of indices needed when the same base number is divided.
explanations.D: We have: (2 × 10^12)/(5 × 10^4). We can then work out 2/5 (which is 0.4) and (10^12)/(10^4). Remember that when dividing indices with the same base number, the powers are subtracted: 0.4 × 10^(12 – 4) = 0.4 × 10^8. To write this in standard form, the value that is multiplied by the power of 10 must be between 1 and 10, so the powers of 10 will be regrouped: 0.4 × 10¹ × 10^7 = 4 × 10^7

explanations.A: It looks like you have divided the indices. Think about the law of indices needed when the same base number is divided.
explanations.B: Almost, but you need to make sure your answer is in standard form
explanations.C: It looks like you have divided the indices. Think about the law of indices needed when the same base number is divided.
explanations.D: We have: (4 × 10^16)/(5 × 10^2). We can then work out 4/5 and (10^16)/(10^2), remembering that when dividing indices with the same base number, the powers are subtracted: 0.8 × 10^(16 – 2) = 0.8 × 10^14. To write this in standard form, we can group the powers of 10 differently: 0.8 × 10¹ × 10^13 = 8 × 10^13

explanations.A: It looks like you have multiplied powers here. Think about the laws of indices used for division.
explanations.B: We have : (6 × 10^12)/(2 × 10^(–3)). We can then work out 6/2 (3) and (10^12)/(10^(–3)). Remember when dividing indices with the same base number, the powers are subtracted: 3 × 10^(12 – (–3)) = 3 × 10^15
explanations.C: It looks like you have added your indices, 12+ - 3 = 9. Think about the laws of indices and how negative numbers are added and subtracted.
explanations.D: It seems you have divided the powers. Think anout the laws of indices used for division.

explanations.A: It looks like you have multiplied the powers. Think about what law of indices you need to use here.
explanations.B: It looks like you have subtracted 6 from -5. You need to subtract -6 from -5.
explanations.C: We have: (9 × 10^–5)/(3 × 10^–6). We can then work out 9/3 (3) and (10^(–5)/(10^(–6)). Remember when dividing indices with the same base number, the powers are subtracted: 3 × 10^(–5 – (–6)) = 3 × 10^(–5 + 6) = 3 × 10¹
explanations.D: It looks like there is an error with the indices. Dividing the same base numbers will mean you subtract the powers, so -5 - -6.

explanations.A: It seems you have divided the power, but 4 is not a power.
explanations.B: We have: (8 × 10^12)/4. We can then work out 8/4 = 2, noting that (10^12) remains unchanged because all of the number 8 × 10^12 has already been divided by 2. This gives a complete answer of 2 × 10^12
explanations.C: It looks like you have divided both the power and the 8. Think about the place value of the 8 and whether this will change if it is divided by 4
explanations.D: It seems like you have divided everything by 4. Think about what this would look like if 8x10^12 was written as a normal number, and what parts would change when we divided by 4

explanations.A: It seems you have divided the power, but 3 is not a power.
explanations.B: I think you did 3 divided by 6, we have 6 divided by 3
explanations.C: It looks like you have divided both the power and the 6 by 3.Think about the place value of the 6 and whether this will change if it is divided by 3
explanations.D: We have (6 × 10^18)/3. We can then work out 6/3 = 2, noting that (10^18) remains unchanged because all of the number 6 × 10^18 has already been divided by 3. This gives a complete answer of: 2 × 10^18
